Working with Compressibility#

This tutorial highlights how lib-ela handles material compressibility by comparing the behavior of incompressible and nearly-incompressible Neo-Hookean models under uniaxial loading.

Learning Objectives

By the end of this tutorial, you will be able to:

  • Understand the difference between incompressible and nearly-incompressible material models

  • Implement both models using lib-ela’s Neo-Hookean material

  • Compare their stress-stretch responses

  • Interpret the role of bulk modulus in material behavior

Prerequisites

  • Basic knowledge of hyperelasticity

  • Familiarity with Python and NumPy

  • Completion of the Uniaxial Neo-Hookean Demo tutorial

Installation

pip install lib-ela matplotlib numpy

Introduction

In continuum mechanics, many materials are modeled as incompressible when their volume changes are negligible compared to their shape changes. However, true incompressibility can lead to numerical challenges in finite element analysis. A common approach is to use a nearly-incompressible formulation with a large bulk modulus.

In this tutorial, we’ll compare:

  1. A fully incompressible Neo-Hookean model (no bulk modulus)

  2. A nearly-incompressible Neo-Hookean model (with large bulk modulus)

Step 1: Set Up the Models

Let’s start by importing the required libraries and setting up both material models:

 1import numpy as np
 2import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 3from libela.hyperelastic import NeoHookean
 4
 5# Material parameters (MPa)
 6MU = 0.7  # Shear modulus in GPa (700 MPa)
 7K = 2.5   # Bulk modulus in GPa (2500 MPa)
 8
 9# Create material models
10model_incomp = NeoHookean(mu=MU)  # Incompressible
11model_nearinc = NeoHookean(mu=MU, k=K)  # Nearly-incompressible

Step 2: Define the Stretch Range

We’ll analyze the material response over a range of stretches:

1# Create a range of stretch values (60% compression to 40% tension)
2lam = np.linspace(0.6, 1.4, 50)

Step 3: Compute Stress Response

Now, let’s compute the Cauchy stress for both models:

 1# Compute Cauchy stress for both models
 2sigma_incomp = model_incomp.stress(
 3    lam,
 4    params=[MU],
 5    protocol="uniaxial",
 6    stress_type="cauchy"
 7)
 8
 9sigma_nearinc = model_nearinc.stress(
10    lam,
11    params=[MU, K],
12    protocol="uniaxial",
13    stress_type="cauchy"
14)

Step 4: Visualize the Results

Let’s plot and compare the stress-stretch responses:

 1import matplotlib as mpl
 2
 3# Enable math text rendering
 4mpl.rcParams["axes.formatter.use_mathtex"] = True
 5
 6# Create figure
 7plt.figure(figsize=(8, 5))
 8
 9# Plot stress-stretch curves
10plt.plot(lam, sigma_incomp,
11        label="Incompressible ($K = \\infty$)",
12        linewidth=2.5)
13
14plt.plot(lam, sigma_nearinc,
15        '--',
16        label=f"Nearly-incompressible ($K = {K:.1f}$ GPa)",
17        linewidth=2.5)
18
19# Add labels and grid
20plt.xlabel("Stretch $\\lambda$ (–)", fontsize=12)
21plt.ylabel("Cauchy stress $\\sigma$ (MPa)", fontsize=12)
22plt.title("Comparison of Incompressible vs Nearly-Incompressible Response",
23          fontsize=14, pad=15)
24
25# Add legend and grid
26plt.legend(fontsize=10, frameon=True, framealpha=0.9)
27plt.grid(True, linestyle='--', alpha=0.7)
28
29# Adjust layout and display
30plt.tight_layout()

Discussion and Conclusion

The plot clearly shows the difference between the incompressible and nearly-incompressible models:

  • The incompressible model (solid line) enforces zero volume change exactly

  • The nearly-incompressible model (dashed line) allows for small volume changes

  • The difference is most noticeable in compression where volume changes are more significant

In practice, nearly-incompressible formulations are often preferred for their better numerical properties in finite element analysis.

Next Steps

  • Explore how the choice of bulk modulus affects the solution accuracy and convergence

  • Learn about more advanced material models in the Hyperelasticity Theory & Derivation section

  • Try modifying the material parameters and observe their effects on the stress-stretch response

 1# Create a grid of biaxial stretch values
 2lam1 = lam2 = np.linspace(0.8, 1.3, 60)
 3lam_grid = np.stack(np.meshgrid(lam1, lam2))
 4
 5# Compute biaxial stress response
 6sigma_biax = model_nearinc.stress(
 7    lam_grid,
 8    params=[MU, K],
 9    protocol="biaxial",
10    stress_type="cauchy"
11)
12
13# Plot the results
14plt.figure(figsize=(8, 6))
15cs = plt.contourf(lam1, lam2, sigma_biax[0], 20, cmap='viridis')
16plt.colorbar(cs, label=r"$\sigma_{11}$ (MPa)")
17plt.xlabel(r'$\lambda_1$', fontsize=12)
18plt.ylabel(r'$\lambda_2$', fontsize=12)
19plt.title('Biaxial Stress Response (MPa)', fontsize=14)
20plt.grid(True, linestyle='--', alpha=0.7)
21plt.tight_layout()
22plt.show()

Further Exploration

Now that you’ve seen the basic comparison, here are some ways to explore further:

  • Try different loading protocols (e.g., “shear”, “planestrain”) to see how the models behave under various deformation modes

  • Investigate how the choice of bulk modulus \(K\) affects the stress response and numerical stability

  • Compare the computational performance between the two formulations for different problem sizes

  • Explore the effect of material parameters on the stress-stretch response

References

  • Holzapfel, G. A. (2000). Nonlinear Solid Mechanics: A Continuum Approach for Engineering. John Wiley & Sons.

  • Bonet, J., & Wood, R. D. (2008). Nonlinear Continuum Mechanics for Finite Element Analysis (2nd ed.). Cambridge University Press.

Need Help?

If you have questions or run into issues, please refer to the Quick Start Guide guide or open an issue on our GitHub repository.
